climbs.name: Rest and Recovery
climbs.fa: Luke Childers and Josh Brossman in 2013

content.description: The crux is about halfway up the climb in a seam. Stemming works well at the crux. At least this is what I and my partner did. The rock seems fairly blank at times, but hidden holds appear when you need them. You can't see the leader once they are about halfway up and over a bulge. The route is fun!
content.protection: 14 bolts to a two bolt anchor. A 70m rope is needed.
content.location: This is the center route of the 5 routes on the wall. There is a black colored blob of rock near the bottom. You get down from bolt anchors at the top. There is a small roof to the left of the climb.

content.description: The crux is near the bottom at about the first and second bolts. The face here is very technical, and the holds here are thin and small. Above the climbing is much easier, and the distance between bolts seems spaced far apart in one section. Here, my partner and I thought a mid-sized cam could be placed. The climbing is easy though, so it is not necessary.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a two bolt anchor. A midsize cam can be placed between bolts about midway up but is not necessary
content.location:
This is the furthest left bolt line at the crag. There are lots of bushes near the base. You get down from a two bolt anchor shared with

Ketosis

.

climbs.name: Radial Nerve
climbs.fa: Luke Childers and Josh Brossman in 2013

content.description: This climb starts out easy, maybe 5.6, up a slab. There is a lot of green lichen on this slab. The crux is at the 4th bolt at a small overhanging roof. There is a good rest above the crux. From here, follow a shallow, right-facing corner which has some tricky moves.
content.protection: 10 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the rightmost route on the wall. Look for the bolts furthest to the right. You get down from a two bolt anchor.

climbs.name: Ketosis
climbs.fa: Luke Childers and Josh Brossman in 2013

content.description: The first move, at the first bolt, is difficult but is not the crux. There is a good hold here which allows you to work your feet above the overhang. The crux comes at about the third bolt. There is a good undercling hold at the start of the crux. Above, the climb is slightly easier and goes up good holds to the anchor.
content.protection: 8 bolts and a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
On the left side of the crag, look for the first bolt just above a overlap/overhang. There is a short slab below the overhang. You get down from the bolt anchor above shared with

Recovery

. There is another line of bolts to the left which is the route

Recovery

.

climbs.name: AC Separation
climbs.fa: Luke Childers and Josh Brossman in 2013

content.description:
The crux of this route is at the 4th bolt at a small overhang.

Radial Nerve

shares this crux. Once above the 4th bolt, follow a line of bolts on the left. This line goes up a slight arÃªte.
content.protection: 9 or 10 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This shares the same start as

Radial Nerve

. The first 4 bolts are shared by the two routes. This is the furthest right line of bolts on the crag. Descend from a two bolt anchor shared with

Radial Nerve

.
